answers.author: Stephen Driscoll
answers.text:
Rachel, The most difficult part of Performance Measurement is deciding what to do with the data you have collected. Your organization needs to determine 1) the audience (e.g., the citizens, the elected officials, the staff); and 2) use of the reporting (e.g., overall health of the organization; the success of delivery of particular services; budget vs. actual revenue and spending analysis; CORE services performance, etc.)  Until you have decided on the two elements above you will not be able to tell your organizations "story", which is what you ultimate goal is for making you performance measures work for you.

answers.author: Thomas Quist
answers.text:
Stephen makes an excellent point.  It reminds me, also, that it's a good idea to identify the goals of your organization (by department) first, and then try to answer this question: how do we know if we're meeting our goals?  I think that process helps to ensure that your measures don't get too narrowly focused (often times I think we only measure what's easy to measure, regardless of how meaningful it is).

answers.author: Michael Smith
answers.text:
The City of Oklahoma City has developed strategic business plans using a performance management system for all City departments that ties department operations to a strategic business plan. The strategic business plan is organized into programs with each program having an established budget and family of performance measures. The performance measures demonstrate the benefit each City program is providing to citizens and measure progress in achieving departmental goals using the resources allocated to each program. Our program, Leading for Results, provides better information to decision makers and citizens.  
The following link will take you to our public website with strategic business plans, performance measures, and our most recent citizen survey.  http://www.okc.gov/finance_tab/LFRForCitizens/Forms/LFRMetrics.aspx 
Mike Smith
405.297.2268
michael.smith2@okc.gov

answers.author: Randy Webster
answers.text:
Portland Parks & Recreation links performance measures to outcomes of the strategic plan. We use Condition, Intervention, and Perception measures in clusters linked to each outcome. It's important to identify Goals and/or desired Outcomes, ideally stemming from vision or strategic planning documents. Then develop the indicators that measure progress towards those goals. Otherwise it is difficult to choose relevant indicators from all the numbers that could be reported.  See our Strategic Plan for the outcomes and measures. See our Annual Performance Report for the most recent examples.
http://www.portlandonline.com/parks/index.cfm?a=261145&c=38306
http://www.portlandonline.com/parks/index.cfm?a=380692&c=38306

author: Rachel Leininger
text: Our city is preparing to roll out performance measures for 2012.  We are hoping to gain a better understanding of the quality and efficiency of our services as well as have more data driven discussions with both council memebers and citizens.  Eventually we would like to benchmark ourselves with other communities.  So far the hardest part seems to be developing those key performance indicators that actually determines what you measure.  Has anyone else developed performance measures for their Parks and Recreation Departments or Customer Service Departments?  Were certain measures more helpful/reliable than others?  Any response is helpful as we embark on this journey.  Thanks!
title: Performance Measures: Parks and Recreation and Customer Service Departments
